item.title: Accidents and patterns in nature
item.description: The most important problem in modern natural science is the ratio of accidents and laws in nature. We can talk about this problem as a matter of chaos and self-order. This issue has been considered closely in science relatively recently, but chaos theory already occupies a leading position in the scientific environment. The Newtonian picture of the world was an ordered structure of physical laws. It can also be called deterministic - all phenomena need to be explained and the causes of appearance or manifestation established. But over time, with the development of science, it became clear that not all phenomena obey our usual physical laws. The simplest way to study is idealization. It is always easier to consider the right objects, to develop concepts for them. Therefore, mathematicians have always sought to reduce calculations to even straight, regular circles and triangles. But our world does not consist of perfect figures. You will not see a stone in the shape of an ideal ball, a mountain that is a cone or even structure of sand dunes in the desert. The real picture of our world cannot be idealized. However, despite the complex structure of the world around us, in the first place they always sought to answer questions about man. As a set of simple atoms, it was able to form such a complex structure as a person. No mathematical equation could describe this process. Here, for the first time, the concept of self-ordering arose. Considering the phenomenon of morphogenesis, scientists wondered how cells understand which one becomes the skin and which, say, the eye. After all, at the beginning of the formation of the embryo there is not even any center capable of “giving orders.” This process brought to a standstill the science formed over the years. The outstanding scientist Alan Turing is one of the first to try to describe such processes with mathematical equations. In particular, he was able to explain the formation of color in animals. This connection of mathematics and biology served as the beginning of the most important discoveries. So, those phenomena that used to be considered subject to random fluctuations, we can describe with the help of equations? Does this mean that there are structured natural laws? These questions found their answers in chaos theory, one of the outstanding scientists in which was Edward Lawrence. She finally answers the main question posed at the beginning of the essay. How are strict physical laws and random phenomena interconnected. In fact, order and disorder, stability and instability are of the same nature. We are used to considering chaos a manifestation of the unpredictability of our world. However, chaos is sometimes more predictable than our usual phenomena. Here you can mention the butterfly effect. Can the rise of butterfly wings in Brazil cause tornadoes in London? This absurd statement served as the beginning of a new understanding of the causal relationships between phenomena. Finding reasons can get us very far. However, this confirms the existence of chaotic laws. In summary, we are still very far from fully understanding our world. However, the departure from determinism served as the backdrop of a big breakthrough in this area. The connection of laws and accidents is now more clearly felt than ever. And further study of nature and man cannot continue without this truth.

item.title: Predator-Prey Model
item.description:
Model description

The simplest model of interaction of two types of “predator - prey” - Lotka-Volterra model. This two-species model is based on the following assumptions:

  • The population numbers of prey x and predators y depend only on time (the model does not take into account the spatial distribution of the population by occupied territory)
  • In the absence of interaction, the number of species changes by the model Malthus, with the number of prey increasing and the number of predators falling.
  • Natural mortality of the prey and natural birth rate of the predator are considered insignificant
  • The saturation effect of both populations is not considered
  • The rate of increase in the number of prey decreases proportionally predator abundances

$$ \frac{dx}{dt} = -ax(t) + bx(t)y(t) $$

$$\frac{dy}{dt} = cy(t) - dx(t)y(t)$$

In this model, x is the number of victims and y is the number of predators. Coefficient a describes the rate of natural increase in the number of victims in the absence of predators, C-the natural extinction of predators deprived of food in the form of victims. The probability of interaction between a victim and a predator is calculated in proportion to both the number of victims and the number of predators themselves (xy). Each interaction reduces the population of prey, but increases the population of predators (the members are bsa and dxy on the right side of the equation).

Task:

In the forest live x number of wolves eating hares, the number of which in the same forest y. As long as the number of hares is large enough to feed all wolves, the number of wolves grows until the time comes that the food is no longer enough for all. Then the wolves will start dying and their numbers will decrease. In this case, at some point the number of hares will start to increase again, which will lead to a new growth of the wolf population. This cycle will be repeated as long as both populations exist. In addition, the number of flocks is affected by disease and aging. This model is described with the following equation:

$$ \frac{dx}{dt} = -ax(t) + bx(t)y(t) $$

$$\frac{dy}{dt} = cy(t) - dx(t)y(t)$$

$a, d$ - mortality rate

$b, c$ - population growth rates

  1. Plot the dependence of $x$ on $y$ and graphs of functions $x(t)$ from $y(t)$
  2. Find the stationary state of the system.
